title: 114_s2262
content: The Act titled "CT Colonography Screening for Colorectal Cancer Act of 2015" allows for coverage of computed tomography colonography screening as a colorectal cancer screening test under Medicare. The Act "CT Colonography Screening for Colorectal Cancer Act of 2015" amends the Social Security Act to include screening computed tomography colonography as a colorectal cancer screening test under Medicare. Payment for this test will be consistent with payment for similar services under Medicare. Payment for screening computed tomography colonography under Medicare shall not exceed a specified amount based on recognized rates for diagnostic computed tomography colonography. For individuals receiving this screening, coinsurance will be based on the fee schedule for the services provided. No payment under Medicare for colorectal cancer screening test if individual under 50 years or within 23 months of previous screening computed tomography colonography or colonoscopy. The text discusses frequency limits for colorectal cancer screening tests under Medicare, including screening flexible sigmoidoscopy and screening colonoscopy. Amendments are made to include screening computed tomography colonography in the coverage. Amendments to Medicare coverage include adding screening computed tomography colonography for colorectal cancer screening tests, effective January 1, 2017. The amendment to the Social Security Act adds screening computed tomography colonography as a covered service, effective January 1, 2017. Additionally, there will be reports on the status of covering computed tomography colonography as a colorectal cancer screening test under Medicare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit a preliminary report to Congress on the coverage of computed tomography colonography as a colorectal cancer screening test under Medicare. An annual report on the impact of screening CT colonography on Medicare beneficiaries' colorectal cancer screening compliance and utilization rates will also be submitted. The report will analyze the utilization rates of colorectal cancer screening options for Medicare beneficiaries before and after the availability of screening computed tomography colonography. It will focus on the initial and follow-on screenings, including the use of computed tomography colonography as a substitute for previous screening procedures, especially in rural areas. The report will analyze colorectal cancer screening utilization rates for Medicare beneficiaries, especially in rural areas or underserved populations, before and after the implementation of coverage under the Medicare program. Recommendations for legislative and administrative actions will be provided as deemed appropriate by the Secretary.
